Problem 4

Problem 5

Prove Proposition 4.2.6. (Hint: induct on kkk and use Theorem 4.1.6(iv).)

Proposition (4.2.6)

Let EEE be a subset of R\RR, let aaa be an interior point of EEE, and let fff be a function which is real analytic at aaa, thus there is an r>0r > 0r>0 for which we have the power series expansion

f(x)=∑n=0∞cn(x−a)nf\p{x} = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} c_n \p{x - a}^nf(x)=n=0∑∞​cn​(x−a)n

for all x∈(a−r,a+r)x \in \p{a - r, a + r}x∈(a−r,a+r). Then for every k≥0k \geq 0k≥0, the function fff is kkk-times differentiable on (a−r,a+r)\p{a - r, a + r}(a−r,a+r), and for each k≥0k \geq 0k≥0, the kkk-th derivative is given by

f(k)(x)=∑n=0∞cn+k(n+1)(n+2)⋯(n+k)(x−a)n=∑n=0∞cn+k(n+k)!n!(x−a)n\begin{aligned} f^{\p{k}}\p{x} &= \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} c_{n+k} \p{n+1}\p{n+2} \cdots \p{n+k} \p{x - a}^n \\ &= \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} c_{n+k} \frac{\p{n+k}!}{n!} \p{x - a}^n \end{aligned}f(k)(x)​=n=0∑∞​cn+k​(n+1)(n+2)⋯(n+k)(x−a)n=n=0∑∞​cn+k​n!(n+k)!​(x−a)n​

for all x∈(a−r,a+r)x \in \p{a - r, a + r}x∈(a−r,a+r).
Solution.

Theorem 4.1.6(iv) is given above. We will prove the following statement for all k≥0k \geq 0k≥0 by induction:

P(k)=[f(k)(x)=∑n=0∞cn+k(n+k)!n!(x−a)n for x∈(a−r,a+r)].P\p{k} = \br{f^{\p{k}}\p{x} = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} c_{n+k} \frac{\p{n+k}!}{n!} \p{x - a}^n \text{ for } x \in \p{a - r, a + r}}.P(k)=[f(k)(x)=n=0∑∞​cn+k​n!(n+k)!​(x−a)n for x∈(a−r,a+r)].

Base case: k=0k = 0k=0

In this case, P(0)P\p{0}P(0) is the statement

f(0)(x)=∑n=0∞cn(x−a)n for x∈(a−r,a+r),f^{\p{0}}\p{x} = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} c_n \p{x - a}^n \text{ for } x \in \p{a - r, a + r},f(0)(x)=n=0∑∞​cn​(x−a)n for x∈(a−r,a+r),

which holds by assumption.

Inductive step:

Suppose P(k)P\p{k}P(k) holds for some k≥0k \geq 0k≥0. In particular, f(k)f^{\p{k}}f(k) is real analytic with positive radius of convergence (it's at least rrr), so by Theorem 4.1.6(iv),

f(k+1)(x)=∑n=1∞ncn+k(n+k)!n!(x−a)n−1 for x∈(a−r,a+r).f^{\p{k+1}}\p{x} = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} nc_{n+k} \frac{\p{n+k}!}{n!} \p{x - a}^{n-1} \text{ for } x \in \p{a - r, a + r}.f(k+1)(x)=n=1∑∞​ncn+k​n!(n+k)!​(x−a)n−1 for x∈(a−r,a+r).

Reindexing by replacing n→n+1n \to n + 1n→n+1 (which we can do since nnn is just a dummy variable in the sum), we see

f(k+1)(x)=∑n=0∞(n+1)cn+k+1(n+k+1)!(n+1)!(x−a)n=∑n=0∞cn+k+1(n+k+1)!n!(x−a)n\begin{aligned} f^{\p{k+1}}\p{x} &= \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \p{n+1}c_{n+k+1} \frac{\p{n+k+1}!}{\p{n+1}!} \p{x - a}^n \\ &= \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} c_{n+k+1} \frac{\p{n+k+1}!}{n!} \p{x - a}^n \end{aligned}f(k+1)(x)​=n=0∑∞​(n+1)cn+k+1​(n+1)!(n+k+1)!​(x−a)n=n=0∑∞​cn+k+1​n!(n+k+1)!​(x−a)n​

for x∈(a−r,a+r)x \in \p{a - r, a + r}x∈(a−r,a+r). Thus, P(k+1)P\p{k+1}P(k+1) holds are we are done.

Problem 7

Let a,ba, ba,b be real numbers, and let n≥0n \geq 0n≥0 be an integer. Prove the identity

(x−a)n=∑m=0nn!m!(n−m)!(b−a)n−m(x−b)m\p{x - a}^n = \sum_{m=0}^{n} \frac{n!}{m!\p{n - m}!} \p{b - a}^{n - m} \p{x - b}^m(x−a)n=m=0∑n​m!(n−m)!n!​(b−a)n−m(x−b)m

for any real number xxx. (Hint: use the binomial formula, Exercise 7.1.4.)

Explain why this identity is consistent with Taylor’s theorem and Exercise 4.2.1. (Note however that Taylor’s theorem cannot be rigorously applied until one verifies Exercise 4.2.6 below.)

Solution.

By the binomial theorem,

(x−a)n=[(b−a)+(x−b)]n=∑m=0nn!m!(n−m)!(b−a)n−m(x−b)m.\p{x - a}^n = \br{\p{b - a} + \p{x - b}}^n = \sum_{m=0}^n \frac{n!}{m!\p{n - m}!} \p{b - a}^{n - m} \p{x - b}^m.(x−a)n=[(b−a)+(x−b)]n=m=0∑n​m!(n−m)!n!​(b−a)n−m(x−b)m.

If f(x)=(x−a)nf\p{x} = \p{x - a}^nf(x)=(x−a)n is real analytic at bbb, then Taylor's theorem says that

(x−a)n=∑m=0∞f(m)(b)m!(x−a)m.\p{x - a}^n = \sum_{m=0}^\infty \frac{f^{\p{m}}\p{b}}{m!} \p{x - a}^m.(x−a)n=m=0∑∞​m!f(m)(b)​(x−a)m.

On the other hand, Exercise 4.2.1 says

f(m)(b)={n!(n−m)!(b−a)n−mif 0≤m≤n,0if m>n.f^{\p{m}}\p{b} = \begin{cases} \frac{n!}{\p{n-m}!} \p{b - a}^{n-m} & \text{if } 0 \leq m \leq n, \\ 0 & \text{if } m > n. \end{cases}f(m)(b)={(n−m)!n!​(b−a)n−m0​if 0≤m≤n,if m>n.​

Thus, in this case, Taylor's theorem reduces to

∑m=0∞f(m)(b)m!(x−a)m=∑m=0n1m![n!(n−m)!(b−a)n−m](x−a)m,\sum_{m=0}^\infty \frac{f^{\p{m}}\p{b}}{m!} \p{x - a}^m = \sum_{m=0}^n \frac{1}{m!} \br{\frac{n!}{\p{n-m}!} \p{b - a}^{n-m}} \p{x - a}^m,m=0∑∞​m!f(m)(b)​(x−a)m=m=0∑n​m!1​[(n−m)!n!​(b−a)n−m](x−a)m,

which agrees with the binomial theorem.
